review.title: A framework for (under)specifying dependency syntax without overloading annotators
review.abstract: We introduce a framework for lightweight dependency syntax annotation. Our formalism builds upon the typical representation for unlabeled dependencies, permitting a simple notation and annotation workflow. Moreover, the formalism encourages annotators to underspecify parts of the syntax if doing so would streamline the annotation process. We demonstrate the efficacy of this annotation on three languages and develop algorithms to evaluate and compare underspecified annotations.
histories: This is an expanded version of a paper appearing in Proceedings of the 7th Linguistic Annotation Workshop & Interoperability with Discourse, Sofia, Bulgaria, August 8-9, 2013
This is an expanded version of a paper appearing in Proceedings of the 7th Linguistic Annotation Workshop & Interoperability with Discourse, Sofia, Bulgaria, August 8-9, 2013

metadata.title: A Framework for (Under)specifying Dependency Syntax without Overloading Annotators

sections.text: A framework for (under-) specifying dependency syntax without overloading annotators Nathan Schneider, Brendan O'Connor Naomi Saphra David Bamman Manaal Faruqui Noah A. Smith Chris Dyer School of Computer Science Carnegie Mellon University Jason Baldridge Department of Linguistics, The University of Texas at Austin AbstractWe are introducing a framework for the syntax of light dependency. Our formalism builds on the typical representation of unspecified dependencies and allows for a simple writing and annotation workflow. Furthermore, formalism encourages annotators to underline parts of the syntax if this would streamline the annotation process. We demonstrate the effectiveness of this annotation in three languages and develop algorithms for evaluating and comparing underspecified annotations. This paper is an extended version of (Schneider et al., 2013) which includes additional technical details.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: There are a number of linguistic theories based on different purposes and aesthetic principles (Chomsky, 1957; Tesnière, 1959; Hudson, 1984; Sgall et al., Mel, 1988).Formalisms dealing with tractable computation can focus mainly on learning or parsing efficiency (Shieber, 1992; Sleator and Temperly, 1993; Kuhlmann and Nivre, 2006).Other considerations include psychological and evolutionary plausibility (Croft, 2001; Tomasello, 2003; Fossum and Levy, 2012), integration with other representations such as semantics (Steedman, 2000; Bergen and Chang, 2005), or suitability for specific applications.

sections.heading: 2 A Dependency Grammar for Annotation
sections.text: Although approaches to dependence on syntax play an important role in computer linguistics, they are nevertheless able to grasp the complex relationships between the various areas. sections.heading: 2.1 Underspecification
sections.text: (Our desire to facilitate lightweight annotation scenarios requires us to abandon the expectation that syntactic informants provide a complete analysis for each sentence. On the other hand, a annotator may be uncertain about the appropriate parse due to a lack of expertise, insufficiently mature annotation conventions, or actual ambiguity in the sentence. On the other hand, annotation markers may be indifferent to certain phenomena for a variety of reasons, including: • Some projects may only need annotations of specific constructions. For example, building a semantic resource for events may require the annotation of syntactic verb-argument relationships, but not internal annotation structures. • As a project is more mature, it may be more useful to comment only rarely on lexical elements. • Semi-supervised learning from partial an-notations may be sufficient to learn complete annotations (Hwa, 1999; Clark and Curran, 2006).

sections.heading: 2.2 A Formalism, not a Theory
sections.text: Although it standardizes the fundamental treatment of some fundamental phenomena, the simplicity of formalism requires us to be careful with such extensions. Therefore, just as with simpler formalisms, linguistic and project-specific conventions must be developed for certain linguistic phenomena. However, by turning to sub-specific annotations, our formalism aims to promote efficient body coverage in an nascent annotation project without forcing commentators to make hasty decisions.

sections.heading: 3 Syntactic Formalism and GFL
sections.text: We call our formalism Fragmentary Unlabeled Dependency Grammar (FUDG). To simplify the creation of FUDG annotations with a text editor, we offer a plaintext-en-6While some linguistic phenomena (e.g. relative sentences, control constructions) can be represented by non-tree structures, we note that the ability to create annotations when they inadvertently violate the tree constraint is more useful than expressive flexibility.Dependency annotations, which are called Graph Fragment Language (GFL). Fragments of the FUDG graph - nodes and dependencies they link - are encoded in this language; together, these fragments describe the annotation in its entirety. The arrangement of the GFL fragments and tokens within each GFL fragment is unrelated to the GFL-Dnoence, the Fda-Definition is adjacent to the FFL-Deconstruction.

sections.heading: 3.1 Tokens
sections.text: We expect a tokenization, such as a sentence or a short message, and the provided tokenization is respected in the note. For human readability, GFL fragments refer to tokens as strings (not offsets), so any tokens involved in a note must be unique in the annotation.8 A token tag can be referenced multiple times in the note.

sections.heading: 4 Annotation Evaluation Measures
sections.text: Quantifying the Interannotator Agreement on a Common Data Set is an important tool for reflecting on the individual annotators and the general difficulty of the annotation task (influenced by the nature of the data, the annotation process, and the training / guidelines / reference materials available to the annotators).If there is a well-defined set of decisions for each sentence that must be made as they vowed to defend themselves on Tuesdays < defend themselves < and (sworn * to defend themselves (on < Tuesday)), the decisions of the two annotators can be directly compared. However, if the task allows a large margin - as in our case, where a syntactic annotation may be complete or partial - the comparison becomes more difficult. We formalize techniques to compare two annotations in our formalism, bearing in mind that the structure can be sub-specified in different parts or in different degrees of profiles.

sections.text: In fact, it is not the case that we would be able to calculate the notes of two FUDG notes if one of them falls below a part of the dependency structure. A solution is to look at the intersection of the supported full trees in terms of our promiscuity standards. In the case of notes A1 and A2 of the notes, one cannot calculate between two FUDG notes if one of them falls below a part of the dependency structure. A solution is to look at the intersection of the supported full trees in terms of our promiscuity standards. A note of the supported notes can be enumerated by two FUDG notes.

sections.heading: 5.1 Annotation Time

For the two Twitter cases, the same reviewer was initially allowed to leave uncommented all punctuation and any "Twitter discourse" marker that did not participate in syntactic relationships, and then spend the same time commenting all the comments fully. Although this is a very small study, the results clearly indicate that it was able to make much faster progress than a partial remark was an option.14 This pilot study helped us identify linguistic phenomena, which are listed in the Notes below:

sections.heading: 5.3 Annotator Specialization
sections.text: As an experiment in the use of sub-specifications for the division of labor, two of the commentators of review data were assigned specific linguistic phenomena on which to focus. Annotator "D" was entrusted with the internal structure of basic nomenclature phrases, including the resolution of precursors of personal pronouns. "C" was asked to mark the remaining phenomena - 18Another example: Some uses of conjunctions such as and so could be interpreted either as phrase coordinators or as discourse connectives (cf. The PDTB Research Group, 2007), i.e. enunciation / sentence / verb phrase structure - but to mark the basic nomenclature phrases as blurred expressions without specifying their internal structure. Both commentators provided a complete lexical analysis. For comparison, a third person, "A," commented on the same data completely. The three commentators worked completely independently of each other.

sections.heading: 5.4 Treebank Comparison
sections.text: Although the commentators in our study were native speakers who were well acquainted with the representations of the English syntax, we tried to quantify their agreement with the tree bank experts, who used a more workable and less error-prone approach when specialists worked sequentially or collaboratively (rather than independently) on each sentence. In fact, "C" and "D" had incompatible annotations on only two sentences, and both were due to simple errors that were then fixed in combination. To turn tree base components into dependencies, we used the PennConverter tool (Johansson and Nugues, 2007) with options chosen to mimic our annotation conventions, 21 and then removed punctuation markers (the combinations).

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We have presented a framework for easy annotation of dependencies that overcomes some of the representative limitations of unlabeled grammar of dependencies and takes into account the practical realities of resource-building efforts. Pilot studies (in multiple languages and domains, supported by human notation and a range of open source tools) have shown that this approach is suitable for quick annotation with minimal training; the next step will be the development of algorithms that exploit these representations for learning parsers; other future enhancements may include additional expression mechanisms (e.g. multi-headedness, labels), crowdsourcing of FUDG annotations (Snow et al., 2008), 22 or even a semantic counterpart to syntactic representation.

metadata.abstractText: We introduce a framework for lightweight dependency syntax annotation. Our formalism builds upon the typical representation for unlabeled dependencies, permitting a simple notation and annotation workflow. Moreover, the formalism encourages annotators to underspecify parts of the syntax if doing so would streamline the annotation process. We demonstrate the efficacy of this annotation on three languages and develop algorithms to evaluate and compare underspecified annotations. This paper is an expanded version of (Schneider et al., 2013) containing additional technical details.
